texts.shortText:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

This species is fairly plump with a largish eye and pectoral fin longer than the head. Adult males have a slightly concave snout profile and bulge between the eyes. Mouth is small and lacks molars; front part of operculum scaly (distinguishing it from similar Bronze bream). Colour silvery-bronze on body, streaked with blue, head distinctly blue-tinged. Dorsal fin spines blue. Fin membranes distinctly yellow.
Up to 50 cm total length and a mass of up to 5 kg.

Global: Endemic to South Africa

Local/Regional: False Bay to Sodwana Bay.
Found on rocky reefs to a depth of about 75 m, juveniles usually more inshore at 10–20 m.
Feeds on a wide range of benthic invertebrates, particularly hydroids, tunicates and octocorals.
First matures as female at a length of 20–25 cm and then changes sex to become male at a length of 20–30 cm (age of 4–9 years). Spawns from September to March, eggs developing in the plankton.

Easily confused with the two other Pachymetopon species in the region. The Hottentot P. blochii (which is much the most common of the species) has a smaller eye and is fairly plain bronzy-brown. The Bronze bream P. grande is plumper with a smaller head and is bronze brown with a blue tinge on head. The anterior part of the operculum lacks scales.
